metadata.title: How to Evaluate Machine Learning Model Performance in Python? | Towards Data Science | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: How to Evaluate Machine Learning Model’s Performance in Python
metadata.description: Welcome! Are you ready with your cool machine learning model trained on millions of data points and now you want to test its performance but you don’t know where to start with or what could be a…

all_paragraphs: Welcome! Are you ready with your cool machine learning model trained on millions of data points and now you want to test its performance but you don’t know where to start with or what could be a better way to do so?

In this article, we would be discussing everything you need to know to test your model's performance whether it be a Classification model or a Regression model, in this article we will dive deep into the understanding of a machine learning model’s evaluation process which is indeed a very crucial step for a Machine Learning Engineer or a Data Scientist.

Let’s start with the understanding of how we can evaluate a classification algorithm. A classification model predicts the output as a class label. Let us assume there is a random variable ‘xᵢ’, so the predicted value of xᵢ is ‘yᵢ’ labeled as:

Below are some very useful ways to measure the performance of a Classification model. In our study below we will be mostly dealing with binary classification for ease in understanding the concept, which can easily be extended for multi-class classifications.

Accuracy tells us about the number of correctly classified data points with respect to the total data points. As the name suggests, accuracy talks about how close the predicted values are to the target values.
Accuracy = # of correct classified points / # of total points
But accuracy is not always a good measure for model evaluation because of its simplicity in assumption. Let us see these two cases where accuracy is not a good measure.

Confusion Matrix is one of the core fundamental approaches for many evaluation measures in Machine Learning. Confusion Matrix is an “n-dimensional” matrix for a Classification Model which labels Actual values on the x-axis and the Predicted values on the y-axis.
Generally, for a binary classifier, a confusion matrix is a 2x2-dimensional matrix with 0 as the negative class and 1 as the positive class.
For a good model, the principle diagonal elements of the confusion matrix should be high values and off-diagonal elements should be low values.

Each cell in a confusion matrix plays a very important role in understanding the model's performance. TN, FN, FP, TP are the names given to each cell based on their actual and predicted values in the cell. Let’s understand them one by one and then we’ll find some amazing relations from them.
TN = True Negative (Data which was actually negative and was correctly classified in a negative class by the model).
FN = False Negative (Data which was actually positive but was wrongly classified in a negative class by the model).
FP = False Positive (Data which was actually negative but was wrongly classified in a positive class by the model).
TP = True Positive (Data which was actually positive and was correctly classified in a positive class by the model).
There is a simple way to remember them, the first alphabet answers the question “Are we correct?” and the second alphabet tells about “Predicted Value”.
There some amazing relations between these notations which are going to be very useful for our evaluation. Before that let's see what are actually positive and actual negative values.
Positive (P): The sum of the False Negative and True Positive values is the actual set of positive values in the data. P = FN+TP
Negative (N): The sum of the True Negative and False Positive values is the actual set of positive values in the data. N = TN+FP

Now that we know the cell notations and the positive and negative notations, there are 4 important measures that are calculated using these notations which are very useful for model performance estimation. They are as follows:
They sound a bit confusing but when we look at the confusion matrix and find these relations pictorially, then they start to give some sort of sense.
For a model to perform well “TPR and TNR should be high values” and “FPR and FNR should be low values”.

Precision and Recall are used mostly in cases of information retrieval. For a binary classification problem, these two metrics are mostly focused on the positive class. Yes, the positive class. Now, let us look at the formulas of Precision and Recall with respect to the confusion matrix in Fig 3 below. We can clearly see that the complete focus of both precision and recall is on the True Positive cell of the confusion matrix and they have nothing to deal with the True Negative.
Precision: Of all the points that the model predicted to be positive, how many of them are truly positive.
Recall: Of all the actually positive points, how many of them the model predicts as positive.

Precision and Recall both values are in the inclusive range of [0, 1] and we always want both of them to be as high as possible. Sometimes it's good to combine two different values instead of analyzing them separately, so to combine them we have a metric named F1-score which is the “Harmonic Mean of Precision and Recall”.

F1-score is sometimes used as a metric for model evaluation in case of some competitions at Kaggle.com but it is a bit hard to understand in simple English whereas Precision and Recall are separately more interpretable.
Let’s Implement this in Python 3.x. Below is a manual Implementation of model evaluation using a confusion matrix.
Here, is the sample output for the above code implementation.

Receiver Operating Characteristic curve or ROC is the plot of TPR vs FPR forming a curved line representing values of TPR and FPR for the various threshold values “𝜏”. AUC is the area under the curve. Together they are sometimes referred to as AUROC (Area under the Receiver Operating Characteristic) curve.

Given a threshold parameter 𝜏, the instance is classified as a positive class if X>𝜏, and negative class if X<=𝜏. X follows a probability density f1(x) if the instance actually belongs to the positive class, and f0(x) if it belongs to the negative class. Therefore, the true positive rate is given by:
and the false positive rate is given by:
The ROC curve plots parametrically TPR(𝜏) vs FPR(𝜏) with threshold 𝜏 as the varying parameter over the plot which gives the shape like the one shown in Fig 4 Receiver operating characteristic curve.

AUC is the area under the curve. AUC lies in the range of [0, 1]. The value of 0.5 means that the model’s performance is random. The value of AUC in the range of [0.5, 1] concludes that the model performs pretty well, whereas the AUC value in the range [0, 0.5] talks about the bad performance of the model.
“Higher the value of AUC better is the model performing.”

There is a very simple trick to handle then model performance when AUC gets in the range of [0, 0.5]. Trick: “Simply switch the class labels predicted by the model.” Yes, suppose we get AUC of 0.32 then after switching the class labels 0 to 1 and 1 to 0, we get an AUC value of 1–0.32 = 0.68 which makes it a good model. It’s that simple!

Log-Loss is used to find model performance for Binary Classification algorithms which can be easily extended for multi-class classifications. It takes into consideration all the probability scores predicted by the machine learning model and computes the loss with respect to the real values of ‘yᵢ’ and the predicted value ‘p(yᵢ)’ using the formula in Fig 5 below.

It’s simple to understand this formula, for each yᵢ=1, the value log(p(yᵢ)) is added to the loss whereas, for each yᵢ=0 the value log(1-p(yᵢ)) is added to the loss which is then computed over the mean by dividing the calculated sum by N (number of data points).
Simply, Log-Loss is the average negative log(probabilities of correct class label)
In simple terms, we can say that when ‘p(yᵢ)’ is low, which means the model predicts a more uncertain value for ‘yᵢ’ then the penalty for it is more and Log-Loss is more and vice versa.
Predicted Probability ⬇ ⇒ Log-Loss ⬆
Predicted Probability ⬆ ⇒ Log-Loss ⬇
Look at Fig 6 below to understand this inverse relation between predicted probability and Log-Loss.
With that said, now let’s see how we can implement log loss. Below is the code implementation in Python3.
But Scikit-learn provides a single line of import to compute Log-Loss as,

One disadvantage of using Log-Loss is its a bit hard to interpret as we can't say anything just by seeing some value for Log-Loss. This is because Log-Loss does not a limited range of output values, it lies from 0 to Infinity. For example, if we get a value of Log-Loss = 12, then we can't say anything just by seeing this value.

The difference between the classification and regression algorithms is the output of classification belongs to a class whereas the output of the regression algorithm belongs to the real number as yᵢ ∈ ℝ.
Let yᵢ is the real-valued output for an input xᵢ and ŷᵢ(y-hat) is the predicted real-valued output of the regression algorithm. So, error eᵢ is calculated as:
So let’s see various types of model evaluation techniques used for regression model performance measurements.
First, let’s understand the Sum of Squares(SS) which is the sum of square difference values of the ‘yᵢ’ of a random variable ‘xᵢ’. Here ‘ȳ’(y-bar) is the mean fo all the values of ‘yᵢ’.
In simple terms, Sum of Squares (SS- total) is the sum of squares of error for its real value with respect to its mean value.
Sum of Squares(SS- residue) is the sum of squares of error for its real value with respect to its predicted value.
Let’s consider a few cases based on which we can get some intuition about the model performance when we see the R² value.
Let’s see the implementation of R² in Python3
Scikit-Learn provides a single line import to compute R².
One important point to note is R² do not perform very well in some cases:

Data with outliers: If we have some outlier in data then R² is not a very good means to compute regression model performance, error value gets instantly boost up and in turn affects the R² value drastically. So in such cases, we will use the concept of Median Absolute Deviation which is discussed in the next section.

Since outliers have a great impact on error ‘eᵢ’ so MAD solves this issue by computing the median of all the error values and compute their absolute deviation from each error value which helps in calculating the MAD value and which in turn vanishes the effect of an outlier from the error value.

Median and MAD are robust to outliers. The smaller value of median and MAD tells that the model performs very well. Remember, we could have used Mean or Standard Deviations but they could not handle outliers whereas MAD has no significant effect of outliers.

Note: Plotting the distribution of errors helps a lot in understanding about the outliers and how the error value is spread. The more the distribution is “Right Skewed”, the better is the model is performing. This means most of the points have a low error and there are very few points having high error value which are not significant and can be normalized using MAD.
So, with this, we have come to the end of this article. Now you might be comfortable enough in evaluating your model without any fear!
and many more at Paras Varshney.
If you learned something new from this article or enjoyed reading it, then share it so that others will feel it. Feel free to leave me a comment.
